column1: Oconomowoc ( 'ohk-a-no-mo-waak') is a city in Waukesha County

The source of the explosion was an old gas line that had been capped off sometime in 1972–73; it ruptured after having been struck by a backhoe as utility work was being done on Wisconsin Avenue in preparation for reconstruction of the street.

column1: Oconomowoc schools are served by the Oconomowoc Area School District (OASD). Elementary schools (grades pre-K through 4th) include: Greenland Elementary
column5: and Ixonia Elementary. Oconomowoc has two middle schools
column6: Silver Lake and Nature Hill Intermediate school
column7: which serve students in 5th through 8th grades. These opened for the 2008–2009 year
column8: replacing the older Oconomowoc Middle School. As of the 2018–2019 school year
column10: 715 students.St. Matthew's Lutheran School is a Christian 3K-8 grade school of the Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod in Oconomowoc.Holy Trinity Lutheran School is a Christian 2K-8 grade school of the Evangelical Lutheran Synod in Oconomowoc.

column1: Primary automobile transportation is provided by highways 16
column3: and I-94. Highway 16 runs from Pewaukee to La Crosse. The original route passes through downtown Oconomowoc; however
column4: a bypass was built which goes around Lac La Belle to the north. Highway 67 runs from Beloit to Chillton. Interstate 94 provides access to Madison and Milwaukee.

column1: Amtrak's Empire Builder passenger train passes through
column3: Oconomowoc. The nearest Amtrak train station is Milwaukee Intermodal. Freight rail service is provided by the Canadian Pacific Railway.
has its western terminus at the Collins & Cross Parking Lot station. The service offers daily rides between Oconomowoc and Milwaukee.

column1: The Wizard of Oz premiered at the Strand Theatre in Oconomowoc on August 12
La Belle Cemetery was the first cemetery in Oconomowoc. Originally called Henshall Place
column2: it opened in 1851 on land that is now part of Fowler Park. It later moved to Walnut Street. When the grounds became overcrowded
column3: Charles Sheldon donated land for a new cemetery
column4: and in 1864 the Wisconsin Legislature approved the transfer of burials from Walnut Street to the current La Belle Cemetery grounds on Grove Street.
